Posts.Content: ishobie wrote: My oncologist and I decided that maybe I needed some help with the emotional side of my treatments. I was dx'd in April of 2010, lost my beloved 14 yr old dog, the same week and have been on auto pilot since. I just finished my 4th treatment of TCH, which I have had very bad side effects from. I am usually home in bed for 10 days despite all the meds I am getting. Anyway I went for a session with the psychologist on their staff yesterday. She was very good, very kind, very compassionate. As soon as I got into the office with her I burst into tears. We talked about my dog passing, the grief over her, my surgery, the anger I have felt about losing her and getting cancer.  I never realized how much emotion has been bottled up in side of me these past 4 -5 months. Sadness, anger, fear, all of that came pouring out. I fetl so much better talking to somebody who understood and where I felt I could cry like a baby ~~~ I plan on going back every couple of weeks for the remainder of my treatments.  If anyone feels like I did and do, I really think counseling is a great idea. It won't make these feelings go away, but at least I am not walking around today, at least, all tense and sad. Isabel 4/2010 DCIS, IDC 0.7 CM, HER2+ 0/6 negative Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: My first counseling session ishobie ishobie

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2010 07:19PM ishobie wrote: Penn Stater- my face starting breaking out one week after my first treatment of taxotere, carboplatin and herceptin... my oncologist felt it might have been from the steriods i was given in my IV.. she gave me clindamycin ointment and told me to clean my face with stridex.. in three days it was gone.....!!!!!!!!!!! isabel
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2010 01:54PM ishobie wrote: I stopped chemo in september, still on  herceptin. i have a full head of hair now, short, but its thick n nice n soft. However, its GREY, i was a blonde, so at some point I will color, but not yet. It is as long as that little girl, emma watson, from Harry Potter, she cut it real short. I wish i had the nerve to wear it like this, i am so sick of wigs.  I started using this treatment for thinning hair by phyto and i think it has helped a lot.  I started it as soon as i saw some hair growing, which happened about 4 weeks after chemo stopped. It really will help to feel normal again when my hair is longer and blonde.Does that sound vain? I hope not.....I had such a horrible time with chemo and finally I feel physically better.  My oncologist said you can never tell how long it will take for hair to grow back, Im assuming close to a year. happy holidays everyone isabel
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2010 07:19PM ishobie wrote: cheyenna I have lost 7 pounds since starting chemo and im little to begin with. My first TCH in june was not that bad, my second treatment knocked me on my butt.  I can't keep anything inside, i have too keep baby wipes instead of toilet paper in the bathrooms  I am existing on banana freezer pops and toast with jelly, that is all i can stomach.  The 8 days after this treatment have kept me home and out of work and just plain sick.  I hope I can return to work next week  Didn't expect this to be so tuff.  another 4 to go and herceptin for 9 months..... which should feel like a breeze after chemo  --you have metal mouth by chance, its lovely :))))))))))))))))))))))))) like i am sucking on a metal lollipop

Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2010 05:48AM ishobie wrote: My red blood count is now only 9 and it should be 12. I asked her if adding iron and red meat (which I don't normally eat) would help and she said no, that this is only related to the chemo and what it does.  I am sooo tired.  I  am working part time during my treatments and I get home at 2 and sleep for 3 or 4 hours. I have 2 more treatments of TCH to go and then 9 months of herceptin. I get so very sick, gastro, from the TCH that this last treatment I was determined to stop my treatments at 4. I had a very small tumor, SNB was negative and no lymph nodes involved. My family has talked me out of not continuing since I have come this far. I just feel so crappy and DREAD my next treatment on the 3rd of September. My oncologist said if my RBC has dropped anymore I would need a transfusion first. Sometimes I can't believe what my life has come to :) NOT FUNNY, but I have to try to maintain a sense of humor or I would put my head under the covers.
Posts.Title: Chemo June 2010 Del9 grneyd5600

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2010 10:11PM ishobie wrote: i developed some acne after my first treatment,(mine is TCH) my oncologist said it was more than likely from the steriods I get in the IV, she told me to go back to the old STRIDEX PADS and gave me a RX for clindamycin ointment--it was cleared up in about 4-5 days. Not sure if it is the same with you, but it can't hurt to ask the doctor. isabel
Posts.Title: AC and acne yellow78 seh

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2010 11:46PM ishobie wrote: mine started really slowly after my first treatment of TCH, i had long straight blonde hair and I was finding alot of hair on my clothes, uniforms from work (medical field) so i went to my hairdresser and friend and he shaved it, not totally, but like a Marine buzz. after my second treatment, it came out in the shower --i already had a great synthetic wig, that looked just like my hair..so people still say to me, so you didn't lose your hair with the chemo  that is how good it looks. Losing my hair was really difficult for me, but now with my chemo behind me, it is starting to grow back slowly and it doesn't seem all that important now. Dont worry, you will do fine isabel
Posts.Title: How does the hair start falling? melania lago

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2011 08:52PM ishobie wrote: My breast surgeon told me i wouldnt need chemo but once they did my surgery and the pathology showed 0.7 cm IDC 0/6 nodes---my oncologist said i had to do 4-6 treatments of chemo/herceptin and then 9 more months of herceptin. All she had to tell me was that even if one cell escaped I would have a recurrence and it would be mets.  Nobody can make a decision for you but I want to know I have done everything I can to beat this.  Right now I have two more months of herceptin and I m done. My oncologist said i have less than a 5% chance of recurrence since I did all this treatment and those are damm good odds. Chemo is rough believe me, but I am glad I did it. Good luck with your decision...... think on it. Isabel

I am so very glad to be over the chemo and just doing herceptin, I could dance.. A little memory loss is okay.  Isabel

Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 08:04AM ishobie wrote: I do agree with your surgeon. My sentinel node biopsy was negative and the 6 nodes they took out were also. However, they did find a very very small invasive tumor -so I was not only DCIS anymore but IDC.  My oncologist explained to me that even with a small chance that some cells had escaped my breast, why would I take a chance?My chemo was considered prophylactic. It wasn't easy but if it takes away even a bit of a chance of recurrence, it was worth it. You really can't know for sure what is going on there until the surgery and the final pathology report. He is probably just preparing you for the "might' of what may be. I wish you luck and you are in my  prayers and remember - it may be a tough road, but you can get through it and come out smiling on the other end. I never thought I would feel this much better and I am still on herceptin, but I am slowly feeling like my old self. Isabel

Posts.Content: May 6, 2011 08:21PM ishobie wrote: Hi Kat So sorry bout your dx. I went through this last April, still can't believe it has been a year now. I was dx'd with DCIS initially and IDC 0.7 cm HER 2+ after my mastectomy. I had to have chemo and herceptin, chemo for 5 months and then herceptin till may. next week is my last treatment. It is scary and overwhelming. But just know that you can get through it.  One step at a time, one hurdle a day.  When you know more about the plan of treatment, you ask questions, get second opinions. I got opinions from two oncologists before I proceeded. These boards are so helpful, especially during the anxiety ridden times. Even when you just feel lonely and lousy from treatments, it is so helpful. You are in my thoughts and prayers, keep us posted Isabel
